body.p: To His Excellency Thomas E. Bramlette Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky --

The undersigned your Petitioners would state that he was indicted at the late Term of the City Court of Louisville on a charge of permitting and suffering Gaming in his house Whereby money was lost and won. Knowing the fact that men had gambled in his house and although he had not sanctioned the practice, yet he had not prevented it, he determined to make no resistance to the Indictment, but confessed and was Fined in the statutory fine of Two Hundred Dollars -- costs of course --

He would most respectfully and truly represent that he is a young man And has just commenced business And that persons much older than himself, for their own amusement, profit or gratification made Free with his house And played games of Cards in it; And that he young and inexperienced felt a delicacy in stopping the games and ordering the gentlemen to desist. Therefore he thinks that he in a measure was imposed upon. He will however know better in future and dispense with all false delicacy on the subject -- He will not be laid liable again to such Indictments.
He states that he is poor, just commenced business, scarcely twenty one years of age, not making much money. And that the payment of this heavy fine would be onerous upon him -- He therefore asks your Excellency to remit the same, and prays that the same be fully and entirely remitted And as in duty bound will ever pray &c
We the undersigned personally acquainted with James H. Cornell the petitioner would most respectfully request your Excellency to pardon him and remit the fine --
I recommend Mr James H Cornell to the clemency of the executive for two reasons; first his youth and inexperience & secondly for his manly confession

Richard T. Jacob
Taylor P. Smith
Robt A. Hamilton
W. W. Durant
J. D. Osborne
Will. G. Holden
Capt 23d Ky Inspect
Louisville Ky
Geo. D. Prentice
John H. Howe
I respectfully Join in the prayer of the petitioner -- having sufficient reason for the so doing

Most of the Gentlemen who have signed the foregoing Petition, I presume are personally
know to the Governor, two of them are officers of the city. I write with them, on the ground of the youth & Inexperience of the Petitioner and his former excellent moral standing & good deportment

Geo. W. Johnston.
Phil Tomppert Jr C C C L

Louisville City Court
vs
J. H. Cornell
$200 --

Remit all except costs and fees of Atty
Sept 24th 1863
